Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Adam Martin at the University of Notre Dame. The discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in July 2012 has placed the high-energy physics community in a unique, exciting place -- having available a machine dedicated to pushing into unexplored territory and a new tool, the Higgs boson, to utilize. This project aims to capitalize on this situation by squeezing the most physics out of the existing LHC dataset, looking for hints of other particles and/or forces. The hints of new particles/forces arising as the result of this project can be searched for in detail once the second phase of the CERN LHC begins in mid-2015. This work has a broad impact in that it will guide future experimental searches and involves close collaboration with experimenters, both at Notre Dame and at CERN.

Professor Martin's research project involves two complementary approaches. One approach is to make sure there are no `holes' in the data where new physics could hide. This requires improving existing searches, adapting searches to alternative scenarios, and even motivating new searches. Examples would include nearly degenerate supersymmetric particles, where one decays into the other with a macroscopic decay length. The second approach is to use the Higgs boson as an indirect probe of new physics, studying its properties in detail and looking for deviations. In particular, much needs to be done regarding the differential "moments" of Higgs production. Both approaches require a mixture of model building and collider physics. To further broaden the impact of this project, Professor Martin will collaborate with QuarkNet, an NSF-funded outreach program for high school teachers and students. He will act as an particle physics mentor, providing basic theory context for the hands-on QuarkNet activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first run of the LHC was incredibly successful, having unearthed the last ingredient in the Standard Model -- the Higgs boson -- in 2012. The facility is now in the midst of a second run, at higher energy and intensity, and the particle physics community is hard at work proposing new places to look to find the next new phenomenon. With this broad goal in mind, the research supported by this grant pursued two primary directions, 1.) to study the Higgs boson at high precision and look for any deviations from its expected properties, and 2.) to hunt for Dark Matter, physics that astronomy and cosmology tell us is present (and far more abundant that our 'normal' matter) yet we have so far not been able to see it in terrestrial laboratories. A synopsis of my main results can be broken down according to these categories.

My work on Higgs properties aimed to be model independent, meaning it did not make any assumptions about the properties of any potential new particles other than that they interacted with the Higgs. Instead, my work focused on proposing measurements, e.g. studying Higgs that are very energetic and produced in association with top or bottom quark, that are particularly sensitive. This work produced 3 papers, involved close collaboration with experimental particle physicists. It also took me, rather unexpectedly, into a more mathematical direction. 

While Dark Matter could consist of a single particle, there are many reasons to expect that there are actually many 'dark' particles that can interact with us and each other -- after all, `visible' matter has an incredibly rich structure (many particles, atoms, etc.) despite making up only 5% of the energy budget of the universe.  These 'dark sector' scenarios are theoretically motivated and avoid many of the problems present in simpler models, however the same features that help dark sectors avoid problems make them difficult to discover. My work focused on better ways to detect dark sectors at the LHC and potential future colliders. In particular, I developed a strategy to look for dark sectors in two steps. First, one looks for a dark sector state produced in association with a standard particle; since the dark sector states are practically invisible this will show up in the detector as a visible particle seemingly recoiling against nothing. Using this `unbalanced' signature as a clue that something funny is going on, the event can be further scrutinized for low energy particles coming from the transition from one dark sector state to the next.  This work resulted in 6 journal papers and one proceedings, and the basic technique I worked on has been adopted by the LHC experiments.

Finally, during the course of this award there were several exciting anomalies that popped up at the LHC and that I worked to explain, such as the 750 GeV diphoton excess and the strange Higgs decays to one muon and one tau ( in total, 2 proceedings plus 5 papers). Chasing anomalies is part of the job of every particle theorist as it forces us to throw out our old biases and get creative. While the anomalies to date have all faded away, the techniques developed will be useful for future projects.

This research was all carried out in parallel with my ongoing work in: teaching physics at the undergrad and graduate level, and working with high school teachers and students through the QuarkNet and Masterclass outreach programs
